description: A traditional event to drive away evil spirits and bring in good fortune.
A festival featuring the traditional demon masks and rituals to ward off evil.

Shunsetsu means Spring Festival. History of Chinatown in Yokohama begins with Japan's opening of Yokohama port to foreigners in 1859. Today it is the largest Chinatown in Japan. Every year about 18 million tourists visit the town. Streets and tangled alleys include more than 200 restaurants and over 300 shops which market Chinese products. Highlight of the festivity includes a fantastic parade of people in traditional wardrobes accompanied by dragon dances and lion dances.
A festival celebrating the blooming of ume (plum) trees in Koishikawa Korakuen, which features a central pond and hills, making it perfect for a stroll.
The Kawazu-zakura cherry blossoms are famous for being some of the earliest-blooming cherry blossoms in Japan, with large pink flowers that bloom for about a month.
An exhibition showcasing winter peonies at Ueno Toshogu Shrine, famous for its Kan-botan (winter peonies).
A festival celebrating the ume blossoms at Kameido Tenjin Shrine, which enshrines Sugawara Michizane, a god of learning.
A festival held in Kairakuen, one of the three most famous parks in Japan, featuring about 3,000 plum trees.

festival_name: Ta-asobi (Fertility festival or Rice field ritual)
description: A traditional ceremony reenacting the various tasks of rice production to pray for a plentiful harvest.
A festival for girls where traditional Hina Dolls are displayed, celebrating the Hina Matsuri on March 3.
A traditional ceremony held at various temples and shrines to drive out evil spirits and welcome good fortune.
